title: An International Conference Exploring Community Based Initiatives aimed at Countering Terrorism
abstractText:
Although counter-terrorism policy and practice has traditionally been dominated by approaches based on the recruitment and use of informants, ‘hard’ policing strategies such as stop and search, and the use of surveillance, for some time now, innovative, community-focussed approaches to countering terrorism, involving partnerships between individuals, community groups and state agents, have existed in many different contexts. 

This proposal seeks to bring together, in the form of an international conference, key policy makers, practitioners, community members and researchers who are involved in community-based approaches to counter-terrorism, from Egypt, the UK, US, alongside other countries.

The conference will bring together policy makers, practitioners, community members and researchers involved in community-based approaches to counter-terrorism in Egypt, the UK and US and other countries in order to discuss and present experiences so as to highlight different models of work here and to discuss issues of what constitutes good practice in this field, how might success be measured and how might initiatives best be evaluated?  It will also reflect upon diverse community, practitioner and other experiences over the last fifteen years, pre and post 9/11, to ask questions about:

 

  •  What has been accomplished?
  •  What serves to alienate communities ?
